Jinghui Liu

Physics PhD Candidate @MIT

Academics

Jinghui Liu is currently a graduate student in Department of Physics, MIT. She started in the department in 2016, after completing her undergraduate training at Peking University with a Bachelor’s degree of Science in Physics.

She joined in Fakhri Lab located in Physics of Living Systems Center since 2017, and has been working on the series of intriguing projects at the crossing of living systems and non-equilibrium physics since. In her undergrad she had a research background working on the nonlinear dynamical properties of cancerous signaling networks in Ouyang Lab.

Check out her published and ongoing works at Publications, Google Scholar, and ORCID.

Awards

Jinghui is the recipient of the 2016-2017 Morton E. Goulder Presidential fellowship in MIT. She is a finalist for GSNP Student Speaker Award at APS 2020 (virtual). More recently, she has been chosen to speak at the Rising Stars in Soft and Biological Matter Symposium, held by UChicago.

Jinghui has participated in a number of academic conferences in the role of a student speaker. E.g. Check out the following two websites for recorded versions of her talks:

2019 Dec, Flatiron Institute "Universality: Turbulence Across Vast Scales"

2019 May, Boston University "Theory of living systems Meeting"

Activities

Jinghui has been an active officier of her MIT graduate dorm’s committee in 2016-2018. She is currently working as a student member for MIT’s departmental Resources of Easing Friction and Stress group.
